channel.title: Deven's Program Development

item.title: Deven's Program Development
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:17, topic:451226”][quote author=devenb123 link=topic=554113.msg4058693#msg4058693 date=1343242475]
thenewboston’s youtube ones
[/quote]
For future reference, his tutorials aren’t very explanatory, and you don’t really learn how to ‘program’.

surely it shouldn’t particularly matter though since after it’s closure nothing else will attempt to reuse it?

[quote author=veer link=topic=554113.msg4058692#msg4058692 date=1343242457]
In this context it may be fine, but you should be wary of the potential bugs that arise when you unintentionally close System.in and later reattempt to use it.[/quote][/quote]

In this context it may also [b]not[/b] be fine, seeing as to whether System.in can be closed is fully implementation-dependent... the behavior is essentially undefined. Don't toy around with undefined behavior, especially if you're just starting out.

Read full topic

item.title: Deven's Program Development
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“veer, post:13, topic:451226”]I’d actually advise NOT closing the Scanner as it will attempt to also close the underlying InputStream, i.e. System.in. In this context it may be fine, but you should be wary of the potential bugs that arise when you unintentionally close System.in and later reattempt to use it. In this context it may also not be fine, seeing as to whether System.in can be closed is fully implementation-dependent… the behavior is essentially undefined. Don’t toy around with undefined behavior, especially if you’re just starting out.[/quote]i’d only suggested it because of the @SuppressWarnings(“resource”) expecting that to be complaining about resources not being closed, but actually that’s good to know. surely it shouldn’t particularly matter though since after it’s closure nothing else will attempt to reuse it? or were you referring to how this guy may attempt to use it after

Read full topic

item.title: Deven's Program Development
item.dc:creator: @devenb123 devenb123
item.description:
@devenb123 wrote:

thenewboston’s youtube ones… So here is my codeimport java.util.*; public class Name { public static void main (String[] args){ System.out.println("Let's start the game :P"); number(); name(); } public static void number() { System.out.println("What is your favorite number?"); Scanner numberget = new Scanner(System.in); int favnumber = numberget.nextInt(); System.out.println("Your favorite number isn't " + favnumber + " moron"); } public static void name() { System.out.println("Let's try your name...."); System.out.println("Now don't lie, What is your name?"); Scanner namer = new Scanner (System.in); int name = namer.nextInt(); System.out.println("Well, then welcome " + namer); } }

and here is the output

Let's start the game :P What is your favorite number? 9 Your favorite number isn't 9 moron Let's try your name.... Now don't lie, What is your name? Deven Exception in thread "main" java.util.InputMismatchException at java.util.Scanner.throwFor(Unknown Source) at java.util.Scanner.next(Unknown Source) at java.util.Scanner.nextInt(Unknown Source) at java.util.Scanner.nextInt(Unknown Source) at Name.name(Name.java:18) at Name.main(Name.java:6)

Read full topic

item.title: Deven's Program Development
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

I’d actually advise NOT closing the Scanner as it will attempt to also close the underlying InputStream, i.e. System.in. In this context it may be fine, but you should be wary of the potential bugs that arise when you unintentionally close System.in and later reattempt to use it. In this context it may also not be fine, seeing as to whether System.in can be closed is fully implementation-dependent… the behavior is essentially undefined. Don’t toy around with undefined behavior, especially if you’re just starting out.

Read full topic

item.title: Deven's Program Development
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“devenb123, post:8, topic:451226”]Dude what the fuck? I don’t know what you just said… this is my first day… I need english. PS I took out string args and it created 2 errors[code]import java.util.*;
public class Name {
public static void main (String[] args){
System.out.println(“Let’s start the game :P”);
System.out.println();

}
public static void number {
System.out.println(“What is your name?”);
Scanner namer = new Scanner(System.in);
int favnumber = namer.nextInt();
System.out.println(“Your name isn’t " + favnumber + " moron”);
}
public static void name {
System.out.println(“Let’s try your name…”);
System.out.println(“Now don’t lie, What is your name?”);
Scanner string = null;
String name = string.nextLine();
System.out.println("Well, then welcome " + name);
}
}[/code][/quote]wow do i have to spoonfeed or will you take incentive in future

[code=java]import java.util.Scanner;

public class Game {

private static Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

public static void main(String[] args) {
    System.out.println("Let's start the game :P");
    System.out.println();
    
    number();
    name();
}

public static void number() {
    System.out.println("What is your name?");
    int favnumber = scanner.nextInt();
    System.out.println("Your name isn't " + favnumber + " moron");
}

public static void name() {
    System.out.println("Let's try your name....");
    System.out.println("Now don't lie, What is your name?");
    String name = scanner.next();
    System.out.println("Well, then welcome " + name);
}

}[/code]

test run:

[code]Let’s start the game

What is your name?
4
Your name isn’t 4 moron
Let’s try your name…
Now don’t lie, What is your name?
Frog
Well, then welcome Frog[/code]

i’m guessing that’s what you want, study what i did

Read full topic

item.title: Deven's Program Development
item.dc:creator: @devenb123 devenb123
item.description:
@devenb123 wrote:

Dude what the fuck? I don’t know what you just said… this is my first day… I need english. PS I took out string args and it created 2 errors[code]import java.util.*;
public class Name {
public static void main (String[] args){
System.out.println(“Let’s start the game :P”);
System.out.println();

}
public static void number {
System.out.println(“What is your name?”);
Scanner namer = new Scanner(System.in);
int favnumber = namer.nextInt();
System.out.println(“Your name isn’t " + favnumber + " moron”);
}
public static void name {
System.out.println(“Let’s try your name…”);
System.out.println(“Now don’t lie, What is your name?”);
Scanner string = null;
String name = string.nextLine();
System.out.println("Well, then welcome " + name);
}
}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Deven's Program Development
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“devenb123, post:5, topic:451226”][quote author=s1gma link=topic=554113.msg4058633#msg4058633 date=1343239319]

@SuppressWarnings("resource") hmmm?

might wanna scanner.close(); at the end
[/quote]
Why would I close it if i want to use it later? Also I want to run the 2 new voids i just created, how do i make them run in my main class?

[code]import java.util.*;
public class Name {
public static void main (String[] args){
System.out.println(“Let’s start the game :P”);
System.out.println();

}
public static void number(String args[]){
System.out.println(“What is your name?”);
Scanner namer = new Scanner(System.in);
int favnumber = namer.nextInt();
System.out.println(“Your name isn’t " + favnumber + " moron”);
}
public static void name(String args[]){
System.out.println(“Let’s try your name…”);
System.out.println(“Now don’t lie, What is your name?”);
Scanner string = null;
String name = string.nextLine();
System.out.println("Well, then welcome " + name);
}
}
// wait[/code][/quote]i’m going off the code you presented, not your future intentions. you should have just closed the scanner at the end of the main method anyway, and performed any logic before that so that it’s ‘correct’ even when extending. if you want to invoke methods (not ‘run voids’) then use (…), and despite this, you shouldn’t need a String[] as an argument for both name and number so remove the argument, make the Scanner reusable between each method and call them like name(); and number();

Read full topic

item.title: Deven's Program Development
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

You don’t need “String[] args” as a parameter for the two non-main methods.

Also don’t make a new instance of Scanner in each method.

Read full topic

item.title: Deven's Program Development
item.dc:creator: @devenb123 devenb123
item.description:
@devenb123 wrote:

[quote=“s1gma, post:4, topic:451226”]@SuppressWarnings("resource") hmmm?

might wanna scanner.close(); at the end[/quote]
Why would I close it if i want to use it later? Also I want to run the 2 new voids i just created, how do i make them run in my main class?

[code]import java.util.*;
public class Name {
public static void main (String[] args){
System.out.println(“Let’s start the game :P”);
System.out.println();

}
public static void number(String args[]){
System.out.println(“What is your name?”);
Scanner namer = new Scanner(System.in);
int favnumber = namer.nextInt();
System.out.println(“Your name isn’t " + favnumber + " moron”);
}
public static void name(String args[]){
System.out.println(“Let’s try your name…”);
System.out.println(“Now don’t lie, What is your name?”);
Scanner string = null;
String name = string.nextLine();
System.out.println("Well, then welcome " + name);
}
}
// wait[/code]

item.title: Deven's Program Development
item.dc:creator: @devenb123 devenb123
item.description:
@devenb123 wrote:

Please move if this is in wrong place.
Here is my first code, remember it’s my first day.

[code]import java.util.*;

public class Main {
@SuppressWarnings(“resource”)
public static void main (String[] args){

Scanner scanner =  new Scanner(System.in);

System.out.println("What is your favorite number?");
int favnumber = scanner.nextInt();

System.out.println("Your name isn't " + favnumber +  " moron");


}

}
[/code]
